item.title: A Field Guide to Lies & Stats - Levitin 2016
item.description: Summary Numerical plausibility Misleading averages Misleading axes Nefarious reporting Decrease hiding in the cumulative Unrelated plotting Irrelevant differences Comparing apples and oranges Probabilities in court Probability The prosecutor’s fallacy Bayesian updating Summary Bit unsatisfying. Good compilation of mistakes to avoid/ tricks to look out for when reading research and/or arguments. However, given his psychologist/neuroscientist angle I was hoping for more of a general thread pulling the examples together concerning why the human brain is fooled by particular presentations rather than just what those presentations are.
